awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Novel Camera-Projector Device Leveraging Markerless Skin Registration and Projected Augmented Reality Software to Enable Navigation for Minimally Invasive Procedures
awd_abstract_narration:
This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is a novel projection-based platform, enabling direct visual mapping during surgical procedures. The project aims to develop a system that directly projects images that guide surgical intervention in real time onto the patient. By enabling direct visualization and by requiring minimal consumable components, the project aims to address usability and cost barriers that hinder adoption of current surgical mapping platforms. This product targets the spinal lumbar surgical market accounting for nearly 200,000 U.S. procedures each year. Spinal surgery requires high levels of accuracy, with inaccurate interventions resulting in reoperation rates of up to 16%, and readmissions costing nearly $15 billion in both direct and indirect costs, as well as poorer patient outcomes. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project aims to develop and validate a novel, projection-based, surgical navigation platform. The system utilizes three dimensional sensors to non-invasively orient to each individual patient and project visual anatomical references and guidance onto their skin surface, aiding surgeons in real time. This project will develop and validate the hardware and software to repeatably and reliably detect and align radiological images onto patients.  It will also develop and validate the core algorithms needed to ensure the required accuracy and system performance suitable for surgical use. The prototype will be tested on bench-top phantoms and its performance compared to the defined industry-standard accuracy measures required for lumbar spinal surgical procedures.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
During this SBIR Phase I project, Illuminant Surgical aimed to develop Skylight™, a cost-effective surgical navigation system that can be set up without invasive procedures and can project augmented reality guidance on the patient without the need for worn equipment such as goggles.

With Phase I funding, Illuminant successfully developed key pieces of hardware and software critical to Skylight’s core innovations. Key milestones because of this Phase 1 Include:

Milestone 1: Design and Fabrication of an Optical Head Assembly. Illuminant successfully designed, fabricated, and assembled a robust optical assembly with aluminum components to ensure rigidity. This design optimally aligns the optical components necessary for precise projection mapping, which is crucial for accuracy.

Milestone 2: Development of High-Accuracy Camera-Projector Calibration Algorithm.  A custom calibration algorithm was created which achieved subpixel precision.

Milestone 3: Development of Distortion Compensation Algorithms for Projection Mapping. A virtual projection technique was successfully implemented, allowing the system to project undistorted images onto non-planar surfaces, providing smooth real-time correction that minimizes distortions on complex anatomical surfaces. 

Milestone 4: Development of Non-invasive Registration Algorithms. Illuminant developed a non-invasive method to align radiographic images onto the body that is both accurate and robust, supporting precise navigation in spinal procedures.

Milestone 5: Demonstrate Clinical Utility and Feasibility of Projection Mapped Guidance. Illuminant performed formative user testing with surgeons on phantoms and cadavers. From these sessions, the projection mapping user interface was demonstrated to have clear visibility and be easy to use.

This system configuration allows Skylight to function as a portable solution that is easy to deploy in diverse healthcare environments, from major hospitals to smaller surgical centers. These accomplishments mark a significant step toward making high-quality, projection mapped-assisted surgical navigation more widely available for minimally invasive spine surgery. The demand for spinal care is steadily increasing in the U.S. due to an aging population, with case volumes projected to rise each year. Annual direct costs for spinal surgeries already amount to hundreds of billions of dollars, and indirect costs, such as loss of productivity and workforce impact, add further strain. This economic burden is placing pressure on the U.S. healthcare system and affects the broader economy. 

By enabling higher precision, Skylight improves spine surgery outcomes, reduces errors, and minimizes the need for corrective surgeries, ultimately increasing access to high-quality spinal care for hundreds of thousands of patients. Skylight’s accessible, cost-effective design has the potential to become a standard tool for spine surgery, reducing procedural risks and expanding access to advanced navigational capabilities in both large and small healthcare facilities. Broad adoption of Skylight across the U.S. will not only alleviate pressures on the healthcare system but also improve patient outcomes, enhance quality of life, and support the health and independence of our aging population.


Last Modified: 11/07/2024
Modified by: James B Hu
